issues.description: The problem statement specifies a method checkOrderReady() with no parameters (UML and textual description), but the solution implementation defines checkOrderReady(boolean enableLogging). This changes the method signature (additional parameter) compared to the specification and will confuse students about the intended API. Students implementing checkOrderReady() as described in the statement (no arguments) will produce a different public API than the solution, and any tests or references expecting the no-argument method would not match the solution signature.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution's checkOrderReady method match the specification: provide a public void checkOrderReady() with no parameters. If logging control is needed internally, use an internal/private helper or a class-level flag instead of changing the public signature. Alternatively, update the problem statement/UML to document the boolean parameter if that extra parameter is intentional.

issues.description: The problem text instructs students to initialize both the orders array and the stock in the SealSaloon constructor ("These should be initialized ... in the constructor of SealSaloon"), but later explicitly requires the stock attribute to be static (shared across all instances). Initializing a static shared field in an instance constructor is contradictory guidance. The solution declares stock as a static final field and initializes it at declaration rather than in the constructor. This inconsistency in the problem statement (initialize in constructor vs. static shared field) may confuse students about where and how to initialize the stock.
issues.suggested_fix: Clarify the problem statement: state that the orders array should be initialized in the instance constructor, while the stock is a static (class-level) field that may be initialized at declaration or in a static initializer. Explicitly indicate that the shared static stock should be defined as static final and can be initialized at declaration, so students are not instructed to initialize a static field in the instance constructor.

issues.description: The problem statement / UML specifies a no-argument method checkOrderReady(): void on SealSaloon, but the solution implements checkOrderReady(boolean enableLogging) and calls it from orderMeal as checkOrderReady(true). This changes the method signature (adds a parameter) and therefore breaks the direct mapping between the UML/requirements and the implemented API. Students expecting to implement or call checkOrderReady() with no arguments (as described in the problem) will be confused by the extra boolean parameter in the reference solution and by the differing usage in orderMeal.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the solution with the problem specification by restoring the no-argument signature: public void checkOrderReady(). If internal debug logging is desired, either (a) use a private overloaded helper like private void checkOrderReady(boolean enableLogging) and keep the public no-arg method delegating to it, or (b) control logging via a private field or logger so the public API matches the UML and student expectations. Also update all calls (e.g., orderMeal) to call checkOrderReady() with no arguments.
